body:
I'm one of the "others" who feels the same way.

Downsides of calling #to_a on inspect:

From a completely selfish perspective:

* If you're hacking on AR (via gem or otherwise) in ways that affect `build_arel`, failing specs have a great chance to hang and generate "stack level too deep" errors (or, "object doesn't support inspect" messages) under Ruby 1.9.x, as something involved in `to_a` raises,  inspect gets called, calling `to_a`, raising... you get the idea.

From a more typical-user-facing perspective:

* Inspection of objects in an error raised in development mode will cause extremely slow rendering if an unbounded relation is one of the objects being inspected.

From a code correctness perspective:

* If I'm calling inspect on an object, I want to inspect that object. Not the results of running some method on that object. If I wanted to inspect that, I'd have inspected that. Seeing the `@where_values`, `@select_values`, etc on the Relation has a lot of value to a developer.
